stem: A 42-year-old client was found pinned under a fallen wall for 6 hours. He has had an emergent fasciotomy for compartment syndrome. Based on the documentation, complete the bowtie by selecting the most likely condition, the two actions the nurse should take, and the two parameters the nurse should monitor.

tabs.title: SBAR
tabs.content:
Situation: Rule out acute renal shutdown following crush injury.
Background: Crush injury to lower leg. Fasciotomy performed.
Assessment: Urine in the bag is 'dark tea' colored. Muscle pain is generalized.
Recommendation: Stat CK and alkaline diuresis.

tabs.title: Nephrology & Myoglobin Log
tabs.content:
Assessment ItemResultInterpretation
Creatine Kinase (CK)84,000 U/LMassive Muscle Death (> 5000)
Urine MyoglobinPositive (Large)Nephrotoxic Pigment
Serum Potassium (K+)6.2 mEq/LHyperkalemia (Cell lysis)
Urine ColorDark brown / ColaMyoglobinuria

tabs.title: Vital Signs
tabs.content: BP 138/92, HR 102, RR 18. Urine output: 10 mL / hr.

actionOptions.text: Initiate high-volume IV Normal Saline (200 mL/hr) to maintain urine output
Monitor for cardiac rhythm changes related to hyperkalemia
Instruct the client to avoid all fluids
Apply ice packs to the entire leg

parameterOptions.text: Urine color and Hourly Urine Output
Serum Creatine Kinase (CK) and Potassium (K+) levels
Daily measurement of fasting serum glucose
Presence of a positive Trousseau sign

rationale.correct: This is Rhabdomyolysis leading to Acute Tubular Necrosis (c2). When muscle is crushed or dies (as in compartment syndrome), it releases Myoglobin. Myoglobin is toxic to the renal tubules. The high CK (84,000) and tea-colored urine confirm this. Priority #1 is aggressive hydration (a1) to 'flush' the pigment through the kidneys. Priority #2 is managing the Potassium (a2), as muscle cell death (lysis) releases massive amounts into the blood. Monitoring must track the 'Pigment' (p1) and the 'Electrolytes' (p2).
clinicalPearls: The goal in rhabdomyolysis is to maintain a urine output of at least 200â€“300 mL/hr.
Creatine Kinase (CK) level is the most sensitive lab indicator of rhabdomyolysis.
If the urine doesn't clear, the patient will likely need emergent hemodialysis.

questionTrap.trap: Restricting fluids because the urine output is low.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Usually, for kidney failure, you restrict fluids. But for *Rhabdomyolysis*, you do the opposite. You MUST push fluids to prevent the 'sludge' (myoglobin) from plugging the kidneys permanently.

mnemonic.title: Pigment Plug
mnemonic.expansion: P-Painful muscles. I-Increased CK. G-Ground-tea urine. M-Massive IV fluids. E-Electrolytes (K+) up. N-Necrosis of kidneys. T-Toxic pigment.
